daewoo

Ok, so it is older than dirt. When I got it, the thing was cutting edge. Now I can't erase the memory card, so I can only change about 7 of the songs (it really only hold 14)
 
 Anybody know anything about these things? If I buy a new memory card for it is it likely to straighten up its act?
Master_Shake
I haven't heard of it, but it sounds interesting. Could you tell us more about it or give us a website where we could see it and read about it?
daewoo

There is a review of it at :
 
 http://www.neoseeker.com/Articles/Hardware/Reviews/rcakazoo/
 
 I actually got mine at the end of 2000. the one in the article has 64 mb internal, mine only has 32. When I bought the thing it was supposed to be the coolest MP3 player going. It was the bomb. 
 
 To its credit, it is more or less still going strong today. I lost it about 6 months ago, and found it the other day under the tool box in my truck, so it has been out int he weather for about 6 months. I disassembled it and dried it out, and it seems to work fine, except that when I plug it in to change the music on it, it does not access the memory card, only the internal memory. The player sees the card just fine, and I can play the music on it, I just can't change it.
Duo_Maxwell

Sounds like you're going to need to format the card externally. 
 
 Its a MMC and you can likely find someone who has a reader for that. Just format it and you should be good.
daewoo

DAMN. I already went and bought a new card for it. 128 MB at staples for $32. Not as bad as I thought it would be (when I bought the 32 MB card I have been using it was nearly $90, and I haven't priced them since).
 
 New card seems to work fine. I will take the old one into the office and format it there (I know some of the machines have programmers).
